Dear Ms. Aufdemberge:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
November 16, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued.
Please review this report for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(5) An agency shall appoint a social service worker who
possesses at least a bachelor's degree from an accredited
college or university with a major in a human behavioral
science, or in another major where 25% of the course credits
earned toward the degree are in human behavioral sciences.
One of ten new, promoted or transferred social service
workers did not possess a bachelor’s degree with a major
in a human behavioral science or 25% of course credits
earned in human behavioral science.
The employee was hired as a foster care worker on 8/31/20
and recently completed CWTI training. Her major is
American Ethnic Studies. The agency did not consult with
DCWL prior to hiring. Technical assistance about this was
provided at the 2019 inspection.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of ten new, promoted or transferred staff did not have
a performance evaluation within 90 days per Vista Maria’s
policy.
4

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of four 259-forms was not submitted to DCWL within 5
working days of receiving the information.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(c) The allegations.
One of four special evaluations identified and addressed a
rule in the report that was not alleged in the complaint or
determined an additional finding. When the error was
discovered, they were unable to remove the rule due to
MISACWIS limitations.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) – (g)
When cases of two of eight children were transferred to
Vista Maria from another agency, placement outlines/client
information forms were not completed.
(repeat violation from 2019)
5

R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) – (g)

not signed by the worker or supervisor.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of eight foster children had a medical examination
completed 8 days late.
(repeat violation from 2019)
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(1) (a) One of one initial service plan was completed 6
days late (repeat violation from 2019)
(2) (b) Two of 24 updated service plans were completed
4 and 23 days late

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home – upon receiving annual/renewal reports and
special evaluations from the licensing agency, it is
recommended the licensing supervisor date and initial the
reports as verification they are acceptable.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The agency was unable to locate a current foster child’s hard paper file. They
indicated it may be with the child’s former foster care worker who resigned. This
presents a potential confidentiality breach. I recommend the agency continue
to search for the file and compile a duplicate file using uploaded information until the
original file is located.
A foster care supervisor said she typed a birth father’s signature on a PATP in
September 2020 without giving him a copy of the document after COVID home
visit restrictions had lifted. The same supervisor acknowledged the birth mother was
unreachable, yet she typed the mother’s signature on the PATP anyway. Both
signatures were typed in by the supervisor on the same day the report was
completed. *Note – birth parent/caregiver signatures are not required on PATPs
until 30 days after the report is completed. The foster child lives with the father and
in-person home visits had resumed by September. The supervisor could have asked
for the father’s signature at the next home visit and could have written on the
mother’s copy of the PATP that she could not be located. If virtual contacts become
necessary in the future, I recommend emailing the PATP to the relevant parties,
requesting a return email confirming agreement and uploading the email with
the corresponding PATP. If the person does not have email, the PATP could be
mailed, date stamped and returned. Other methods of confirming agreement with
the plan can also be used as long as verification is uploaded with the PATP.
Incomplete and/or unsigned documents should not be uploaded into MISACWIS.
9

The Pediatric Symptom Checklist has no date or signature line. I recommend PSCs
be signed and dated by the foster care worker somewhere on the page in order to
determine when it was completed and by whom.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one safety alert in a foster home as determined by the DCWL Analyst
on 11/4/20. Concern: The foster parent told the analyst she did not have a child’s
medical authorization card. Resolution: She later confirmed to the agency that
she had had the card all along.
During this licensing period, there was one incident of substantiated child abuse
involving corporal punishment by a foster parent. In this instance, a special
evaluation was completed and the agency recommended that foster home license
be revoked.
There were no DCWL investigations on the agency during this licensing period.

statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an

renewal of their regular license.
